q: What are the symptoms of bronchitis?
a: Symptoms of bronchitis can include a cough, chest pain when coughing, shortness of breath, sore throat, runny nose, and high temperature.

q: What can I do to help with bronchitis?
a: You can rest, drink plenty of fluids, take painkillers, add honey to warm drinks, cover your mouth and nose when coughing or sneezing, and wash your hands regularly. Do not smoke.

q: When should I seek urgent medical advice for bronchitis?
a: Seek urgent GP appointment or call NHS 111 if you've had a cough for more than 3 weeks, cough up blood or blood-stained mucus, have chest pain, are over 65 or pregnant, have a long-term condition, have a weakened immune system, or feel very unwell.

q: When should I call 999 for bronchitis?
a: Call 999 if you are struggling to breathe, have pale, blue or blotchy skin, suddenly feel confused, or are unable to wake your baby.

q: How long does bronchitis usually last?
a: Bronchitis usually clears up without treatment in around 3 weeks.

q: Do I need antibiotics for bronchitis?
a: You may need antibiotics if your bronchitis is caused by a bacterial infection. See a GP if your symptoms last longer than 3 weeks.

q: Can bronchitis lead to chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)?
a: Yes, some people who have long-term inflammation of the airways in the lungs called chronic bronchitis can develop COPD.

q: Is it safe to give honey to babies under 1 with bronchitis?
a: No, avoid giving honey to babies under 1 with bronchitis to reduce the risk of infant botulism.

q: What should I do if I have bronchitis but also a high temperature?
a: Stay at home, rest, drink plenty of fluids, and take painkillers like paracetamol or ibuprofen to help with pain and bring down the high temperature.

q: What precautions should I take to reduce the risk of spreading infections if I have bronchitis?
a: Cover your mouth and nose with a tissue when you cough or sneeze and put used tissues in the bin as quickly as possible. Wash your hands regularly with water and soap.
